english_source: The Ikwerre (natively known as Iwhuruọha[1][2]) is widely regarded as one of the Igbo groups in Rivers State.[3][4][5] They are considered as a part of the larger Igbo ethnic group. They speak Ikwerre, an Igbo dialect, which is sometimes considered a separate language[6] in the Igboid family, as a result of the quest for Ikwerre's recognition as a separate ethnic nationality.
target1_text: A na-ahụ Ikwerre (nke a ma ama dịka Iwhuruọha [1] [2] ) dịka otu n’ime ndị Igbo dị na Steeti Steeti. [3] [4] [5] A na-ahụta ha dịka akụkụ nke nnukwu agbụrụ Igbo. Ha na- ako Ikwerre, olu olu igbo, nke a na-ewere mgbe ufodu dika asusu di iche [6] n ’ ezinulo igboid, n’ihi na acho ichota Ikwerre dika obodo ndi ozo.
target2_text: A na-ahụ Ikwerre (nke a ma ama dịka Iwhuruọha [1] [2] ) dịka otu n’ime ndị Igbo dị na River Steeti. [3] [4] [5] A na-ahụta ha dịka akụkụ nke nnukwu agbụrụ Igbo. Ha na- asu Ikwerre, olu igbo, nke a na-ewere mgbe ufodu dika asusu di iche [6] n’ezinulo igbo, n’ihi na ha choro ka ahuta Ikwerre dika agbụrụ kwuru onwe ha.

english_source: Akudo Oguaghamba is a Nigerian human rights activist[1] and educator. She has published articles on LGBTQ- and gender rights.[2] She's the founder for Women's Health and Equal Rights WHER[3][4] and was also a co-chair (Female) of PAN-AFRICAN ILGA (International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association).[5][6] Oguaghamba is an alumnus of University of Nigeria, Nsuuka[7] and EQUITAS – International Centre for Human Rights[8] and has over eleven years leadership and project management experience.

[2] Ọ bụ onye guzobere Health Women na Equal Rights WHER [3] [4] ma bụrụkwa onye isi oche (Nwaanyị) nke PAN-AFRICAN ILGA (International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association). [5] [6] Oguaghamba bụ alumnus nke Mahadum Nigeria, Nsuuka [7] na EQUITAS - International Center for Human Rights [8] ma nwee ihe karịrị afọ iri na otu onye isi na ahụmịhe njikwa ọrụ.

english_source: Glamour Girls is a two-part Nollywood film about independent single women embarking on their own paths within Nigeria's traditionally patriarchal society. [1][2] It gained widespread popularity in Nigeria.[3] The film starred Liz Benson, Ngozi Ezeonu, Eucharia Anuobi, Pat Attah, Ernest Obi, Zack Orji, and others.
target1_text: Glamour Girls bụ ihe nkiri Nollywood nwere akụkụ abụọ gbasara ụmụ nwanyị nọọrọ onwe ha na-abanye n'ụzọ nke ha n'ime ọha ndị nna ochie nke Nigeria. [1] [2] Ọ nwetara ewu ewu na Naịjirịa. [3] Ihe nkiri a bụ Liz Benson, Ngozi Ezeonu, Eucharia Anuobi, Pat Attah, Ernest Obi, Zack Orji, na ndị ọzọ.

[3] Ihe nkiri a gosiputara Liz Benson, Ngozi Ezeonu, Eucharia Anuobi, Pat Attah, Ernest Obi, Zack Orji, na ndị ọzọ.

english_source: The 2016 Best of Nollywood Awards was the 8th edition of the ceremony and took place in Aba, Abia State on 10 December 2016.[1] The event was to be hosted by Okey Bakassi and Mercy Aigbe, with the latter not showing up on the award night.[2][3] Awards were given in 32 categories, with Adesua Etomi, Beverly Naya, Gabriel Afolayan and Alexx Ekubo amongst the winners.[4][5]

[2] [3] E nyere ihe nrite n'ụdị iri atọ na abụọ, Adesua Etomi, Beverly Naya, Gabriel Afolayan na Alexx Ekubo so na ndị meriri. [4] [5]

english_source: Chukwuemeka Ohanaemere (born 9 September 1982),[1] predominantly known as Odumeje, is a wealthy controversial Nigerian clergyman[2] and general overseer of The Mountain of Holy Ghost Intervention and Deliverance Ministry[3] who is noted for his unorthodox methods of healing and exorcism of supposedly demon-possessed individuals.[4]

[4]

english_source: Igalaland has nine traditional ruling councils including the capital Idah. The nine councils each has a chief (onu) who is appointed by religious rite through a complex system of traditional rite and proceedings supervised by the head of the council, the Attah Igala in Idah. The seven Igala councils are: Ankpa, Ajaka, Ugwolawo, Egume, Dekina, Omalla, Olamaboro.Anyigba
target1_text: Igalaland nwere kansụl ọchịchị ọdịnala itoolu gụnyere isi obodo Idah . Ndị kansụl itoolu nke ọ bụla nwere onye isi (onu) bụ onye a họpụtara site na usoro okpukperechi site na usoro mgbagwoju anya nke omenala omenala na usoro nke onye isi nke kansụl, Attah Igala na Idah na-elekọta. Ndị kansụl Igala asaa bụ: Ankpa, Ajaka, Ugwolawo, Egume, Dekina, Omalla, Olamaboro . Anyigba

english_source: Adejoke Aderonke Tugbiyele (born 1977) is a Nigerian-American multidisciplinary visual artist and activist.[1][2] She is known primarily as a sculptor, performer, and filmmaker, but has also worked in painting, drawing, and textiles.[3][4] Her work deals with issues of human rights, queer rights and women's rights.[5][1][6] She lives in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso.[7]

english_source: Radia Bent Lhoucine (1912–1994) was a self-taught Moroccan artist who began painting in her later years, and whose work has been exhibited and sold at galleries in Africa and Europe.

english_source: She was featured in the exhibition titled Two thousand years of Art in Morocco held at the Charpentier Gallery in Paris in 1963. english_source: Takawira was born in the mountainous Nyanga district, third of six children. Their father was often absent for work, and their mother, Mai, assumed a dominant role. She was well known for her knowledge of Shona myths and stories, and would share them with her sons; these tales had a deep influence in both John and Bernard's careers as sculptors.

A maara ya nke ọma maka ihe ọmụma ya banyere akụkọ ifo na akụkọ Shona, ọ na-akọkwara ụmụ ya ndị nwoke akụkọ agbụrụ ha; akụkọ ndị a nwere mmetụta miri emi na ọrụ John na Bernard dị ka ndị na-akpụ ihe.

english_source: Devin Allen is an American photographer, photojournalist, and activist based in Baltimore, Maryland. He gained national attention after the Freddie Gray protests in 2015, when his documentary photograph entitled "Baltimore Uprising" was published as Time magazine's May 2015 cover photo.[1] His documentary photo of the George Floyd protests was published as Time's June 2020 cover.[2]

Ọ nwetara nlebara anya mba mgbe ngagharị iwe Freddie Gray n'afọ 2015, mgbe e bipụtara foto ya akpọrọ "Baltimore Uprising" dị ka foto mkpuchi nke ọnwa Mee afọ 2015 nke magazin Time. E bipụtara foto ya nke ngagharị iwe George Floyd dị ka mkpuchi Time nke ọnwa Juun afọ 2020.

english_source: Igbo Etiti LGA is 325 square kilometers in size and has an average temperature of 27 degrees Celsius. The region has two primary seasons: dry and wet, with total recorded rainfall in the LGA averaging 1900 mm per year. In Igbo Etiti, the average wind speed is 10 km/h.[2]

english_source: In 1902 Keffi was the location of an incident that led to the British invasion of Northern Nigeria, after the "magaji", a representative of the Zaria sultan killed a British officer. When the Magaji found refuge in Kano, this was the pretext for Lugard to invade the northern caliphate.[4][5]
target1_text: N'afọ 1902 na Keffi bụ ebe ihe mere mere ndị Briten ji wakpo Northern Nigeria, mgbe "magaji" gasịrị, onye nnọchiteanya nke Zaria sultan gburu onye uweojii Britain. Mgbe Magaji nwetara ebe mgbaba na Kano, nke a bụ ihe mgbakwasị ụkwụ maka Lugard wakporo caliphate ugwu. [1] [2]
target2_text: N'afọ 1902, Keffi bụ ebe ihe mere nke mere ndị Briten ji wakpo Northern Naijiria, mgbe ahụ "magaji" onye nnọchiteanya nke Zaria sultan gburu onye uweojii Biriteni. Mgbe Magaji nwetara ebe mgbaba na Kano, nke a bụ ihe mgbakwasị ụkwụ mere Lugard ji wakpo caliphate ugwu. [1] [2]

english_source: Oriade is a Local Government area in the northeastern part of Osun State. It is predominantly occupied by the Ijesa people. Its capital is Ijebu-Jesa (or Ijebu Ijesha) in the north of the area at7°41′00″N 4°49′00″E﻿ / ﻿7.68333°N 4.81667°E﻿ / 7.68333; 4.81667.

english_source: Makroudh (Arabic: مقروض, maqrūḍ, Maltese: maqrut), also spelled Makrout, is a cookie from the cuisine of the Maghreb. It is filled with dates and nuts or almond paste, that has a diamond shape – the name derives from this characteristic shape.
target1_text: Makroudh (Arabic: مقروض, maqrūḍ, Maltese: maqrut), nke a na-akpọkwa makrout, bụ kuki sitere na nri Maghreb. Ọ na-ejupụta na mkpụrụ osisi ma ọ bụ mkpụrụ osisi almond, nke nwere ọdịdị dayamondu nke aha ahụ sitere na ọdịdị a.

english_source: Aaronson scored his first goal for Salzburg on February 10, 2021, scoring the game-winning goal during an eventual 3–1 win over Austria Wien.[22] On May 1, he won his first piece of silverware with Salzburg as the club defeated LASK in the Austrian Cup final by 3–0.[2] Aaronson scored the second goal of the match, and his fifth in all competitions since his move from Philadelphia in January.[23]
target1_text: Aaronson gbara goolu mbụ ya maka Salzburg na Febụwarị 10, 2021, na-agba goolu mmeri n'egwuregwu n'oge mmeri 3 Xing1 meriri Austria Wien.[1] N'ụbọchị mbụ n'ọnwa Mee, ọ meriri ọlaọcha mbụ ya na Salzburg ka klọb ahụ meriri LASK na ngwụcha nke iko Austria site na 3[[0.[2] Aaronson gbara goolu nke abụọ nke egwuregwu ahụ, na nke ise ya na asọmpi niile kemgbe ọ hapụrụ Philadelphia na Jenụwarị.[2]
target2_text: Aaronson nyere goolu mbụ ya maka Salzburg na Febụwarị 10, 2021, na-agba goolu mmeri n'egwuregwu n'oge mmeri ha meriri Austria Wien.[1] N'ụbọchị mbụ n'ọnwa Mee, ọ meriri ọlaọcha mbụ ya na Salzburg ka klọb ahụ meriri LASK na ngwụcha nke iko Austria.[2] Aaronson gbara goolu nke abụọ nke egwuregwu ahụ, na nke ise ya na asọmpi niile kemgbe ọ hapụrụ Philadelphia na Jenụwarị.[2]

english_source: The Lagos Police Command is the Lagos State branch of the Nigerian Police Force. It is responsible for law enforcement and crime prevention in the state. The commissioner of this command is often appointed by the Inspector-General of Police. The current commissioner of the state command is CP Abiodun Alabi.[1][2] The current Public Relations Officer of the Command is SP Benjamin Hundeyin. The Lagos State Police Command has different area commands and zones.

english_source: The Lagos State Ministry of Commerce and Industry is the state government ministry, charged with the responsibility to plan, devise and implement the state policies on Commerce and Industry.[1][2] This ministry was established to ensure business Prosperity and Consumer Satisfaction in Lagos state.[3] The head office of the agency is located at Block 8, The Secretariat, Obafemi Awolowo Way, Alausa, Ikeja, Lagos state.[3]

english_source: Elder rights are the rights of older adults(usually those in the seventh decade of life or older, although this definition is disputed), who in various countries are not recognized as a constitutionally protected class,[1] yet face discrimination across many aspects of society due to their age.

english_source: Nyankpa or Yeskwa (nyankpá) is a Plateau language of Nigeria. It sometimes appears in the literature as Nyenkpa, which is a dialect.

english_source: During the dry season, there are lesser rainfalls, more sun and lower humid. This period is falls between October until April every year. It is normal to experience harmattan and dry spell during this period. The harmattan usually appears from December to January.[1] 1983 holds the record as the driest year Nigeria has ever seen since 1981.

english_source: In the Ghanaian view, the black star stands for the unity of Africa. Red stands for the blood shed during the struggle for independence, yellow stands for the sun, and green represents hope.[citation needed]

english_source: Nobulumko Degracia Nkondlo is a South African African National Congress politician who has served as a Member of the Western Cape Provincial Parliament since November 2016. She succeeded former ANC provincial leader Marius Fransman.

english_source: Katonda is the name used to refer to the supreme creator god in the traditional religion of the Baganda people, who are mostly based in present-day Uganda.[1] Katonda is considered as the father and leader of the Baganda pantheon, known collectively as the balubaale (sing. lubaale).[2][3]
target1_text: Katonda bụ aha a na-eji akọwa chi kachasị elu na okpukpe ọdịnala nke ndị Baganda, ndị n'ozuzu ha bi na Uganda nke oge a.[1] A na-ewere Katonda dịka nna na onye ndú nke pantheon Baganda, nke a maara n'ozuzu ya dịka balubaale (sing. lubaale).[2][3]
target2_text: Katonda bụ aha a na-eji ezo aka na chi kachasị elu na okpukpe ọdịnala nke ndị Baganda, ndị na'ozuzu ha dị na Uganda nke oge a.[1] A na-ewere Katonda dị ka nna na onye ndú nke pantheon Baganda, nke a maara n'ozuzu ya dị hi balubaale (sing. lubaale).[2][3]

english_source: According to Hausa myth, Hausa communities have been living in Central Sudan (much of modern-day Northern Nigeria & some part of Niger) for over 2000 years. Daura was believed to be one of the largest Hausa cities of that time. It had queens as head of government that oversee the affairs of the people. During the reign of Queen Daurama, the major source of water for Daura was the Kusugu well. But people were only allowed to fetch water on fridays because of a strange snake that lives inside the well.
target1_text: Dị ka akụkọ ifo ndị Hausa si kwuo, obodo ndị Hausa ebiela na Central Sudan (ọtụtụ n'ime Northern Nigeria nke oge a na akụkụ ụfọdụ nke Niger) ruo ihe karịrị afọ 2000. E kwenyere na Daura bụ otu n'ime obodo ndị Hausa kachasị ukwuu n"oge ahụ. O nwere ndị eze nwanyị dị ka ndị isi ọchịchị na-elekọta ihe omume ndị mmadụ. N'oge ọchịchị Eze Nwanyị Daurama, isi iyi mmiri maka Daura bụ olulu mmiri Kusugu. Mana a na-ekwe ka ndị mmadụ na ya na Fridges n'ihi agwọ a ma ama nke bi n"ime olulu mmiri ahụ.

english_source: Obassi consists of two distinct male gods, Obassi Osaw and Obassi Nsi, who originally occupied the same body. They eventually separated after creating the universe. Obassi Osaw rules over the skies, where humans are born, while Obassi Nsi rules over the Earth, where humans live and die.[1][2][3][4][5] Obassi Osaw is featured more heavily in Ekoi myths involving the creation of natural phenomena.[1][3]

Obassi Osaw na-achị eluigwe, ebe a na'amụ ụmụ mmadụ, mgbe O bassi Nsi na na - na[1][2][3][4][5] A na-egosipụta Obassi Osaw nke ukwuu n'akụkọ ifo Ekoi nke metụtara okike nke ihe okpomọkụ.[1][3]

english_source: Nzame is the supreme creator god featured in the mythologies of the Fang people of Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, and Cameroon. The name is used to refer to a trinity of deities, which included Nzame, Mebere and Nkwa and is also used in reference to Nzame, one of the members of this trinity.[1][2][3][4]
target1_text: Nzame bụ chi kachasị elu nke e gosipụtara na akụkọ ifo nke ndị Fang nke Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, na Cameroon. A na-eji aha ahụ arụtụ aka na atọ n'ime otu nke chi, nke gụnyere Nzame, Mebere na Nkwa ma a na-ejikwa ya ekwu maka "Nzame", otu n'ime ndị otu atọ na otu a.[1][2][3][4]
target2_text: Nzame bụ chi kachasị elu nke e gosipụtara na akụkọ ifo nke ndị Fang nke Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, na Cameroon. A na-eji aha ahụ na'izo aka na atọ n'ime otu nke chi, nke gụnyere Nzame, Mebere na Nkwa ma na na - na "Nzame", otu n"ime ndị otu atọ na otu a.[1][2][3][4]

english_source: Nyambi is a mythical deity of the Hambukushu tribe of Northwestern Botswana. Nyambi is known as a creator, or a supreme being.

english_source: Rumuola is a town in Obio-Akpor local government area, Rivers State, Nigeria.[citation needed] It is one of the most active towns in Port Harcourt, hosting several businesses and organizations.[citation needed]

english_source: Kesra (Arabic: كسرة) or Aghrum aquran in Kabylia, or Arekhsas in Aures, is a traditional Algerian bread[1][2] made from semolina (wheat or sometimes barley).[3] It is usually cooked on a flat grilling tajine over high heat. This bread can be eaten hot or cold, on its own or spread (with butter, jam, honey, etc.), stuffed or dipped in olive oil, accompanied by tajine, etc. It can be served with fermented milk (leben) or curdled milk (raib).
target1_text: Kesra (Arabic) ma ọ bụ Aghrum aquran na Kabylia, ma ọ bụ Arekhsas na Aures, bụ achịcha ọdịnala Algeria nke e ji semolina (ọka wit ma ọ bụ mgbe ụfọdụ ọka bali) mee.[1][2][3] A na-esikarị ya n'elu tajine dị larịị n'elu okpomọkụ dị elu. Enwere ike iri achịcha a na-ekpo ọkụ ma ọ bụ na-ajụ oyi, n'onwe ya ma ọ bụ gbasaa (na bọta, jam, mmanụ aṅụ, wdg), tinye ya ma ọ bụrụ na etinye ya na mmanụ oliv, tinyere tajine, wdg. Enwere ike iji mmiri ara ehi (leben) ma ọ bụ mmiri ara ehi a gwakọtara agwakọta (raib) nye ya.

english_source: Throughout her career Rakotosamimanana was a member of several professional bodies, including the "Groupe d'Etude et de Recherche sur les Primate de Madagascar" (GERP).[1] Other organisations she was involved with include: Malagasy Academy, "Ranomafana National Park" project, IUCN / SSC Primate Survival Commission, the editorial Board of "International Journal of Primatology" and "Lemur News", Society of Human Biometrics, Society of Anthropology of Paris and the International Association of Anthropologists.[2]

english_source: Audo Bako was born in 1924 at the Kaduna police barracks. His father originally from Argungu, Kebbi State. He had served in the police force for 36 years and was appointed as the District Head of Sabon Gari in Kaduna State. His mother Dije was from Mariri, Kumbotso Local Government, Kano State while his maternal grandmother was from Gezawa Local Government, Kano State. He was educated at the Kaduna Government School and the Zaria Middle School.
target1_text: Audo Bako ịhụ na 1924 n'ogige ndị uwe ojii Kaduna .  Nna ya bu onye Argungu, Kebbi State .  Ọ bụ ọrụ ndị uwe ojii awụ iri atọ na isii wee họpụta ya ka ọ bụrụ onye isi mpaghara Sabon Gari na steeti Kaduna .  Nne ya Dije si Mariri, Kumbotso Local Government, Kano State ebe nne ya si Gezawa Local Government, Kano State.  Ọ akwụkwọ akwụkwọ na Kaduna Government School na Zaria Middle School.
target2_text: Audo Bako mụrụ na 1924 n'ogige ndị uwe ojii Kaduna . Nna ya bu onye Argungu, Kebbi State . Nne ya Dije si Mariri, Kumbotso Local Government, Kano State ebe nne nne ya si Gezawa Local Government, Kano State. Ọ gụrụ akwụkwọ na Kaduna Government School na Zaria Middle School.

english_source: After the German attack on the Soviet Union, the complex temporarily served as Göring's headquarters. With the Soviet advance on East Prussia, Göring ordered the destruction of the Reichsjägerhof and on 20 October 1944 the whole complex was set on fire by Göring's custodian.[1]

english_source: Feathered Dreams is a 2012 Nigerian-Ukrainian drama film, directed by Andrew Rozhen, who also stars in the film with Omoni Oboli.[1] The film which is the first collaboration between Nigeria and Ukraine tells the story of a young Nigerian medical student in Ukraine, Sade (Omoni Oboli) who dreams of becoming a singer, but she's faced with several difficulties associated with being a foreigner.[2][3] Feathered Dreams is also the first Ukrainian English-language feature film.[4]
target1_text: Feathered Dreams bụ ihe nkiri ihe nkiri Nigeria-Ukrainian 2012, nke Andrew Rozhen duziri, onye na-esokwa Omoni Oboli na-eme ihe nkiri ahụ. [1] Ihe nkiri a bụ njikọ aka mbụ dị n'etiti Naijiria na Ukraine na-akọ akụkọ banyere nwa akwụkwọ Naijiria na-eto eto na-ahụ maka ahụike na Ukraine, Sade (Omoni Oboli) bụ onye na-arọ nrọ ịghọ onye na-abụ abụ, mana ọ na-eche nsogbu dị iche iche ihu na ịbụ onye mba ọzọ. english_source: After serving four years in the Army, he worked as a radio journalist in Georgia and Maryland, before taking a job in 1974 in Washington, D.C., with the Mutual Black Network.

english_source: Herbert Booth took command of all Salvation Army operations in the British Isles when he was 26. Then, from 1892–1896, he was the Commandant for the Salvation Army in Canada. Next, he was appointed to the Australasian Territory where his health continued to deteriorate. He struggled with depression, but was still very active in his position.
target1_text: Herbert Booth weghaara ọrụ Salvation Army niile na British Islands mgbe ọ dị afọ 26. Mgbe ahụ, site na 1892–1896, ọ bụ onye ọchịagha maka Salvation Army na Canada .  Mgbe nke ahụ ihuenyo, a na-ahụ ya na Territory Australasia ebe ahụ ike ya ihe na-akawanye njọ.  Ọ na-alụ ogụ na ndị mba n'obi, ma ọ ka na-arụsi ọrụ ike n'aka ya.
target2_text: Herbert Booth weghaara ọrụ Salvation Army niile na British Islands mgbe ọ dị afọ 26. Mgbe ahụ, site na 1892–1896, ọ bụ onye ọchịagha maka Salvation Army na Canada . Mgbe nke ahụ gasịrị, a họpụtara ya na Territory Australasia ebe ahụ ike ya nọgidere na-akawanye njọ. Ọ na-alụ ọgụ na ịda mbà n'obi, ma ọ ka na-arụsi ọrụ ike n'ọnọdụ ya.

english_source: At the age of 16, Lucy and her sister Emma went to India to work with the Salvation Army there. Emma married Frederick Tucker in 1888. The Booth-Tuckers soon moved to London because of Emma's failing health, and Lucy followed.
target1_text: Mgbe ọ dị afọ 16, Lucy na nwanne ya nwanyị Emma gara India ka ha na ndị Agha Nzọpụta rụọ ọrụ n'ebe ahụ. Emma lụrụ Frederick Tucker na 1888. Ndị Booth-Tuckers kwagara London n'oge na-adịghị anya n'ihi ahụ ike Emma na-ada ada, Lucy sochiri ya.
target2_text: Mgbe ọ dị afọ 16, Lucy na nwanne ya nọ Emma gara India ka ha na ndị Agha Nzọpụta nwata ọrụ n'ebe ahụ.  Emma ọmụmụ Frederick Tucker na 1888. Ndị Booth-Tuckers kwagara London n'oge na-adịghị anya n'ihi ahụ ike Emma na-ada ada, Lucy sochiri ya.

english_source: He became an officer in 1882 at the age of 17. Most of his earlier career was spent as an officer in the United States. During his time as an officer in the U.S., there was great divisions amongst the American Salvationists. He was known as the peace maker, thus earning him a lot of respect. In 1888, he married Captain Catherine Price.

A maara ya dị ka onye na-eme udo, si otú a na-akwanyere ya ùgwù nke ukwuu. Na 1888, ọ lụrụ Captain Catherine Price.

english_source: Louise af Forselles (1850-1934), was a Finnish philanthropist and salvationist. She was the central figure of the Christian charitable activity in contemporary Finland.[1] She introduced the Salvation Army to Finland in 1889.[2]
target1_text: [1]Louise af Forselles (1850-1934), bụ onye ọrụ ebere na onye ọrụ nke Finland .  Ọ bụ ya bụ onye bụ isi n'akwarụ ebere Ndị na Finland nke oge a.  [1] O webatara ndị agha na Finland na 1889.
target2_text: Louise af Forselles (1850-1934), bụ onye ọrụ ebere na onye nzọpụta nke Finland . Ọ bụ ya bụ onye bụ́ isi n'ọrụ ebere Ndị Kraịst na Finland nke oge a. [1] O webatara ndị agha nzọpụta na Finland na 1889. [2]

english_source: The convention was adopted in Geneva 28 June 1930 and came into force on 1 May 1932. By the end of 1932 ten countries had ratified the convention (Japan, Bulgaria, Spain, Norway, Denmark, Australia, Sweden, United Kingdom, Liberia, and Ireland). Austria in 1960, Luxembourg in 1964 and Malta in 1965 were the last Western European countries to ratify the convention. Canada ratified it in 2011 and as of 2022, the United States has not ratified it.[4]
target1_text: A nabatara mgbakọ ahụ na Geneva 28 June 1930 wee malite na 1 May 1932. Ka ọ na-erule ngwụsị 1932 mba iri akwadowo mgbakọ ahụ (Japan, Bulgaria, Spain, Norway, Denmark, Australia, Sweden, United Kingdom, Liberia, na Ireland). Austria na 1960, Luxembourg na 1964 na Malta na 1965 bụ mba Europe ikpeazụ kwadoro mgbakọ ahụ. Canada kwadoro ya na 2011 na dịka nke 2022, United States akwadoghị ya. [1]

Ka ọ na-erule nsọ 1932 mba iri akwadowo nke ahụ (Japan, Bulgaria, Spain, Norway, Denmark, Australia, Sweden, United Kingdom, Liberia, na Ireland ). Austria na 1960, Luxembourg na 1964 na Malta na 1965 bụ mba Europe ikpeazụ ngwaọrụ ahụ. Canada akwụkwọ ya na 2011 na dịka nke 2022, United States akwadoghị ya. [1]

english_source: Marie Ozanne (1906 – 25 February 1943) was a major in The Salvation Army, and publicly protested about the treatment of prisoners of war as slave labourers by the German army during the Second World War .[1]

target2_text: [1]Marie Ozanne (1906 – 25 February 1943) bụ onye isi na The Salvation Army, ma kwupụta n'ihu nsogbu omume ndị agha German na -emeso ndị ahụ dị ka ndị ọrụ ohu n'oge Agha agha nke amaghị .

english_source: R L Glasspool Charity Trust, known as Glasspool Trust, is a British charitable trust established in 1939 by businessman and philanthropist Richard Louveteau Glasspool.

target2_text: RL Glasspool Charity Trust, nke a maara dị ka Glasspool Trust, bụ ịhụnanya obi ọrụ nke Britain posts na 1939 site n'aka onye ọchụnta ego na onye ọrụ Richard Louveteau Glasspool .

english_source: In 2006, together with the Institute for Fiscal Studies the Nuffield Foundation funded a proposal for a revision of the British tax system.[6] The research project was headed by Nobel laureate Sir James Mirrlees.

target2_text: N'afọ 2006, ya na Institute for Fiscal Studies, Nuffield Foundation kwadoro atụmatụ maka ngbanwe nke usoro ụtụ isi nke Britain. [1] Onye isi oru nyocha a bu onye nturu ugo Nobel Sir James Mirrlees .

english_source: Voices in the Tunnels (Formerly titled "In Search of the Mole People") is a 2008 documentary directed by Vic David, a New York City filmmaker and a graduate from New York University. It explores the lives of people who lived in the New York City Subway tunnels.
target1_text: Voices in the Tunnels (nke akpọrọbu "N'ịchọ ndị Mole") bụ akwụkwọ akụkọ 2008 nke Vic David duziri, onye na-eme ihe nkiri New York City na onye gụsịrị akwụkwọ na Mahadum New York.  Ọ na-enyocha ndụ nke ndị bi na New York City tunnels ụzọ ụgbọ oloko.
target2_text: Voices in the Tunnels (nke a na-akpọbu "Na-achọ ndị Mole") bụ akwụkwọ akụkọ 2008 nke Vic David, onye na-eme ihe nkiri New York City na onye gụsịrị akwụkwọ na Mahadum New York . Ọ na-enyocha ndụ ndị bi na New York City tunnels ụzọ ụgbọ oloko .

english_source: In 1906, Glicenstein returned from a trip to Germany and exhibited his paintings there until World War I broke out and he moved his family to Poland.[1] He took over the Chair belonging to Xawery Dunikowski at the University of Warsaw in 1910.[2] At the end of the war the family lived in Switzerland until they emigrated to London in 1920. During the next eight years he exhibited first in London and later in Rome and Venice.

[1] Ọ weghaara oche nke Xawery Dunikowski na Mahadum Warsaw na 1910. [2] Mgbe agha ahụ biri, ezinụlọ ahụ biri na Switzerland ruo mgbe ha kwagara London na 1920. N'ime afọ asatọ sochirinụ, o mere ihe ngosi mbụ na London na mgbe e mesịrị na Rome na Venice.

english_source: Agatha Crumm is a newspaper comic strip created by the cartoonist Bill Hoest (creator of The Lockhorns) and distributed by King Features Syndicate.[1] The strip ran from October 24, 1977, until 1997.[2] Agatha Crumm was Hoest's third strip, following Bumper Snickers (1974).[3]

english_source: Aggie Mack was a newspaper comic strip about a teenage girl. Created by Hal Rasmusson, it was distributed by the Chicago Tribune Syndicate beginning on September 2, 1946, and concluding on January 9, 1972.[1] It had a 26-year run, with a title change to Aggie during the final six years.

english_source: Black Star International film festival (BSIFF) is a non-profit festival in Ghana founded by Juliet Asante in 2015. It is a festival celebrated annually to bridge the gap between African movie cinema and the global community of movie makers and focuses on the business aspect of film making.[1][2][3]
target1_text: Black Star International film festival (BSIFF) bụ mmemme na-agụnye uru na Ghana nke Juliet Asante akara na 2015. Ọ bụ emume a na-eme kwa afọ iji dozie dị n'etiti ihe nkiri ihe nkiri Afrịka na ndị na-eme ihe.  nkiri n'ụwa niile ma le anya n'azụ ahịa nke ime ihe nkiri. [1] [2][3]
target2_text: Black Star International film festival (BSIFF) bụ mmemme na-enweghị uru na Ghana nke Juliet Asante guzobere na 2015. target2_text: Se Wsi Testamenti (transl. ; Finnish nke oge a: Uusi testamentti) bụ nsụgharị mbụ nke Agba Ọha na Finnish; e bipụtara ya na 1548. Ọ bụ Mikael Agricola, onye bụbu onye isi Ụlọ Akwụkwọ Katidral nke Turku ma mesịa bụrụ Bishọp nke Turku sụgharịrị ya.

english_source: Laila Nur was born on 5 October 1934 in Daudkandi Thana, Comilla. Her father was Abu Naser, a medical doctor, and her mother was Shamsunnahar Mehedi. english_source: Kanailal Niyogi (1924 - 19 May 1961) was an employee of the Indian Railways who took part in the Bengali Language Movement in the Barak Valley in 1961. english_source: On July 1st 2024, Pope Francis presided at an Ordinary Consistory of Cardinals, which approved the canonization of 15 people, including The Massabki Brothers. N'Obí Ndịozi maka nzukọ ọha na eze, Kadinal Marcello Semeraro gosipụtara 'Peroratio', akụkọ banyere ndụ na ọrụ ebube nke The Massabki Brothers, n'etiti ndị ọzọ.[1]

english_source: Haraza is an extinct Hill Nubian language known only from a few dozen words recalled by village elders in 1923.[1] It was spoken in the Jebel Haraza near Hamrat el-Wuz (Rilly 2010:166).[2]
target1_text: Haraza bụ asụsụ ugwu Nubian ekpochapụla nke a maara naanị site na okwu iri na abụọ nke ndị okenye obodo chetara na 1923.[1] A na-asụ ya na Jebel Haraza dị nso na Hamrat el-Wuz (Rilly 2010:166). [2]
target2_text: Haraza bụ asụsụ Hill Nubian nke a na-adịghịzi adị nke a maara naanị site na okwu ole na ole ndị okenye obodo chetara na 1923.[1] A na-asụ ya na Jebel Haraza dị nso na Hamrat el-Wuz (Rilly 2010:166). [2]

english_source: Kadugli, also Katcha-Kadugli-Miri or Central Kadu, is a Kadu language or dialect cluster of the Nilo-Saharan language family spoken in South Kordofan, Sudan. Stevenson treats the varieties as dialects of one language, and they share a single ISO code, though Schadeberg (1989) treats them as separate languages.
target1_text: Kadugli, nke a na-akpọkwa Katcha-Kadugli-Miri ma ọ bụ Central Kadu, bụ asụsụ Kadu ma ọ bụ ụyọkọ olumba nke ezinụlọ Nilo-Saharan a na-asụ na South Kordofan, Sudan. Stevenson na-ewere ụdị dị iche iche dị ka olumba nke otu asụsụ, ha na-ekekọrịta otu koodu ISO, ọ bụ ezie na Schadeberg (1989) na-ewere ha dị ka asụsụ dị iche iche.
